contentrichtext.text: '''Union Pier''' is an [[unincorporated area|unincorporated community]] in [[Berrien County, Michigan|Berrien County]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Michigan]]. It is situated between the [[Lake Michigan]] shore and the [[Galien River]] about five miles north of the [[Indiana]] state border. Union Pier is at coordinates {{coord|41|49|41|N|86|41|33|W}}. The [[ZIP code]] is 49129 and the [[FIPS place code]] is 81400. During the summer of 1914 a colony of Chicago [[Bohemianism|bohemians]], including the writers [[Sherwood Anderson]] and [[Ben Hecht]], vacationed at the "Camp's Cottages" (for the owner Eli Camp) on the Union Pier beach. The local residents were outraged by what they believed were the wild goings-on at "The Nudist Club," as they characterized it, particularly after two local men left their wives for women staying at Camp's. The locals made the situation sufficiently uncomfortable for the vacationers that they did not return the next year.<ref>Rideout, Walter Bates, and Charles E. Modlin (2006). ''Sherwood Anderson''. pp. 187-90</ref> After the end of [[World War II]], many [[Lithuanian Americans|Lithuanian]] immigrants began settling in Union Pier. Although few Lithuanian-Americans remain today, several Lithuanian facilities remain, such as Milda's Corner Market and Gintaras Resort. Union Pier is also one of the few [[Harbor Country]] villages with its own 1 watt radio station, occasionally broadcasting at 87.9 FM using the moniker "Radio Mykros". Programming varies and includes talk and music, some of which is rather obscure and can contain clips from such bands as [[Nektar]], [[Guru Guru]], and [[SBB (band)|SBB]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Berrien County, Michigan}} {{Michigan-geo-stub}} [[Category:Unincorporated communities in Berrien County, Michigan]] [[Category:Lithuanian-American history]]
